page.title: 14COUSLAND - THE POTTERY
page.content: IN COUSLAND, FROM 1770-1796, A POTTERY WAS IN OPERATION, SET UP WITH THE HELP OF THE EARL OF STAIR. THE NEXT POTTERY WAS BEGUN IN 1975 BY BERT SIMPSON, WHO BUILT HIS HOUSE AND WORKSHOP AROUND THE STABLES AND COTTAGE OF JOHN DRYSDALE, THE VILLAGE CARRIAGE DRIVER IN VICTORIAN TIMES. HE USES STONEWARE CLAY FROM STAFFORDSHIRE TO MAKE MUGS, JUGS, BOWLS, COFFEE AND TEA POTS, GOBLETS, POSY DISHES AND LARGER ITEMS SUCH AS BREAD CROCKS AND PLANTERS. HE DECORATES HIS POTS BY PAINTING, BY SCRAFITTO OR BY APPLIED MODELLING TO GIVE A RAISED EFFECT. A SPECIAL STAMP IN THE SHAPE OF TWO POTTERS' WHEELS IS HIS TRADE MARK. ONE ASSISTANT HELPS HIM PREPARE AND WEIGH THE CLAY OR CHECK THE POTS AND ORGANISE THE KILN. .
